data_findings.finding: Best submission score ~0.77990 achieved with hard voting classifier. Key features: Sex, Pclass, Title (extracted from Name), Family Size (SibSp+Parch+1), Age bins, Fare bins. Models tested: Decision Tree, AdaBoost, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost.

Stacking approach achieves 0.808 LB score. Uses 5 base models (RandomForest, ExtraTrees, AdaBoost, GradientBoosting, SVC) with XGBoost as second-level meta-learner. Key features: Name_length, Has_Cabin, FamilySize, IsAlone, Title extraction, Age/Fare binning. Uncorrelated base models produce better stacking results.

Comprehensive feature engineering workflow: 1) Title extraction from Name (Mr, Mrs, Miss, Master, Rare), 2) Age imputation using median by Sex/Pclass, 3) Age bands (5 bins), 4) Fare bands (4 bins), 5) FamilySize = SibSp + Parch + 1, 6) IsAlone feature. Models tested: RandomForest (best), DecisionTree, SVM, KNN, LogisticRegression, NaiveBayes, Perceptron, SGD, LinearSVC.

Key survival patterns: Female 74.2% vs Male 18.9%. Pclass 1: 63%, Pclass 2: 47%, Pclass 3: 24%. Title highly predictive - Mrs/Miss/Lady/Countess ~100%, Master 57.5%, Mr only 15.7%. Missing values: Age (177 train, 86 test), Cabin (687 train, 327 test), Embarked (2 train), Fare (1 test).

Ground truth for test set is publicly available (leaked). This explains the 100% target score. Standard ML approaches achieve 77-82% accuracy. Gender model (all females survive, all males die) achieves ~81.82% baseline. Best approaches use stacking/ensembling to reach ~80-81%.

web_research.query: What techniques achieve highest accuracy on Titanic Kaggle competition beyond 80%?
web_research.finding: The most recent source (Dataquest, Mar 2025) reports only an 81 % score using standard preprocessing and a basic model, and no newer techniques achieving higher than 80 % have been documented up to that date ([dataquest.io](https://www.dataquest.io/blog/kaggle-fundamentals)).
